column4: hello I seem to have run into a serious problem - error in synaptic when installing a kernel update. Now synatic won't start, instead tells me to run manually "dpkg --configure -a" but when I do I get "gzip: stdout: No space left on device" along with a lot of other failure messages. My /dev/sda3 which has 193MB allocated is full, not sure what I must do to fix it.
try: sudo apt-get clean, that will remove downloaded packages and clean up some spave
furthermore I suggest using gparted to make the partition bigger
apt-get clean did not do it. Can I just change the partition size without screwing up the data on my hard drive?
i never had problems resizing. But it is recommended to make a backup before doing so
but im not sure if you have gparted already (you probably cant install it because you dont have any space left). If you dont have it just run the livecd which has gparted on it
you could remove some old kernels
i am checking out the link you sent - I have 11 kernel versions listed
i never do it that way (i use ubuntu-tweak) but sure give it a shot :)
i believe synaptic can do it too, not sure since i always use apt-get
ubuntu-tweak is a nice application for tweaking little things. http://ubuntu-tweak.com/
you can remove those .bak files in /boot
per your suggestion I just tried to install ubuntu-tweak but got this error message: "error: Dependency is not satisfiable: policykit-1-gnome|policykit-1-qt"
i can not help you with that. sorry
